Two questions: 1) The deep network is run in unsupervised RBM mode first to learn features and representations, later it is fine-tuned with back-propagation against a cross-entropy loss function. Is the latter fine-tuning a supervised process? 2) During the RBM phase the weights are used as couplings between the Boltzmann-weighted states, i.e. $$p(\{x_i\}) \propto \exp(-\sum_{i,j} w_{i,j}v_i h_j + \text{biases})$$. But during back-propagation, are the units now logistic units that use the same weights? i.e. $$\sigma(\sum_j w_{i,j} h_j + \text{biases})$$ where $$\sigma$$ is some function like $$1 / (1 + \exp(x))$$

Unfortunately that page seems to be about 8 years old, and many of the links are broken. Here are a few toy examples of exact sampling given a different source of randomness than the target. 1) Suppose you have an unfair coin which is heads with an unknown probability $$p$$, and you want to sample from the Bernoulli distribution $$B(1/2)$$. Flip the coin twice. $$HT \to 0, TH \to 1$$ otherwise repeat. The expected number of flips is finite, and the probability you haven't extracted a fair bit by time $$t$$ drops exponentially with a rate which depends on $$p$$. 2) Suppose there are two players, and you want player A to win with probability $$1/\pi$$, and player B to win with probability $$1-1/\pi$$. You have a fair coin. You can achieve this if you know the binary expansion of $$1/\pi = 0.01010001011111...$$. If the $$i$$th toss is a head, and the $$i$$th digit is a $$1$$, then A wins. If the $$i$$th toss is tails and the $$i$$th digit is $$0$$ then B wins. Otherwise, keep going. It's a nice puzzle to prove this with no computation necessary. The problem is, you can 'settle down' in one part of the space, leaving another part of the space totally unexplored. If you think you have two sample sets from the true distribution, and you compare them, and they look wildly dissimilar, then you probably don't actually have two sample sets from the true distribution. But if you have two sample sets and they look similar, they might both be from the true distribution, or they might both be from some other distribution that is not the true distribution. I think of Markov Chain Monte Carlo as being kind of like exploring a physical space, where you don't know know anything about it. So you're exploring the haunted house. You wander through doors, and you find the kitchen with the bloody tiles, the cobwebby drawing room, the sinister living room, a bedroom with eerie music and mice running over your feet, and so forth. And your friend wanders around, and he finds the same rooms. So you might conclude that you've explored the entire space. And maybe you have, but maybe you missed that little tiny hidden trapdoor to the dungeon! Similarly, with a Markov chain, you might miss a low-probability transition to a high-probability space.

But if variables are stochastic, in the general case we can't know if we're at equilibrium.)

Hi, per the discussion of Hopfield nets in Lecture 11, would it be valid to consider a mapping between them and Markov Random Fields (MRF)? There seem to be several points of equivalence/near-equiv: both are undirected graphs. Weight assignments for specific combinations of activations in a Hopfield net can be modeled as factors in MRFs. The rule for toggling activations feels very much like a greedy non-stochastic variant of Gibbs sampling, and the end objective can be mapped to maximizing system likelihood (minimizing negative log likelihood). Is this indeed valid, or is there a point I'm missing?
Upvotes:

Keep listening to the lectures, and the equivalence will become clearer. A stochastic Hopfield net is the same as a Markov random field. All the factors in the MRF are binary, each one corresponding to a link in the Hopfield net (or Boltzman machine).
